Passwords 2.0 documentation
Passwords 2.0 documentation
  • Commands
Back to top

Commands#

See#

Shows all entries in the database.

pwd_encrypted.see.db_call()[source]#

Collects all entries in db, decrypts the passwords, cleans the data and stores the result in a pickle file.

pwd_encrypted.see.see_answer()[source]#

Generates a Rich table with the db’s search results.

pwd_encrypted.see.call_see()[source]#

Invoked as pwdall, calls the previous functions to show the whole of the db.

Delete#

Cli accessed delete methods for pwd.

pwd_encrypted.delete.db_call(dlt)[source]#

Makes the db call to delete one or more entries.

pwd_encrypted.delete.call_del(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any) → Any#

Collects search query, calls the previous functions. Function that deletes one, several or range of entries in the ‘pwd’ database.

You can call it with pwddlt, and use it in the following form:

  1. Delete non sequential entries. Surround the ids with quotation marks and separate them with a comma:

    pwddlt '435,436'

  2. Delete sequential entries. Envelop first and last ids with quotation marks and separate them with a dash:

    pwddlt '437-439'

    You may include spaces, but they’ll be deleted by the application.

  3. Delete single entry. Write the id:

    pwddlt 66

Search#

Module to house the search function of the app.

pwd_encrypted.search.db_call(search)[source]#

Using the inofrmation sent from ‘srch_question’ function, it’ll call the database and, with this data, it’ll encode the ‘pwdid’ value to int, so as to obtain the ‘context’ value used to encrypt the entry, decrypt the ‘pwd’ value, create a new list with the updated values and send it to a pickle file.

pwd_encrypted.search.srch_answer(query)[source]#

Generates a Rich table with the db’s search results.

pwd_encrypted.search.srch_question(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any) → Any#

Gets search query through command line and calls the other functions.

Accepts one string argument, the query, and its called with pwdsrch.

Update#

Update functionality of the ‘pwd’ database.

pwd_encrypted.update.db_call(answers)[source]#

Using the inofrmation gathered from ‘call_updt’, it’ll call the database and make the update.

pwd_encrypted.update.call_update(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any) → Any#

Invoked as ‘pwdupdt’, calls the previous functions.

Options:

-i

Id integer of the line to update.

-c

Name of column to update.

-u

Update text.

Add#

This module inserts a new password in the database. It collects user input through a cli, checks if the site to upload is already in the database, creates and/or encrypts a password. Uploads it to the db.

pwd_encrypted.add.check_repeats(site)[source]#

We check with the database to see if there’s already an entry with the same site’s name. If there are, we present the information to the user and ask him if he wants to continue inputing the entry or if he wants to abort. In the first case we do nothing and the program continues, in the other, we exit the program.

pwd_encrypted.add.create_encrypt_pwd(pwdinput)[source]#

Collects all information from ‘answr.bin’. Generates password and context value.

pwd_encrypted.add.db_call(answers)[source]#

inserts the new entry in the database.

pwd_encrypted.add.call_add(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any) → Any#

Gathers all information through command line. Calls all other functions. Cli functionality can be accessed by calling pwdadd.

Options:

-s

Site name.

-u

Username.

-p

Password, if you don’t want it to create one fror you.

-l

Length, number of words used to create your password. Keep it low or the encrypted values will be ridiculously long.

-c

Commentary. What is the site about, and shit like that.
